entry.title: Re: The amount of activity type is not correct and how to...
entry.content:
Hello @garyding 

Thank you for your follow-up.

Allocation Structure is located in Finance/Controlling, not in EPPM. Refer to SAP Help “Allocation Structures” For more details.  SAP Help Portal-Allocation Structures

The CO configuration activity (SSCUI/Config Activity 104073 – Maintain Allocation Structures) can be used for this configuration. SAP KBA also references the use of activity 104073.SAP Support Portal-3363594 - Error KD503 "Complete allocation structure &" happens during settlement - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

EPPM projects consume CO settlement settings (project settlement uses allocation/source structures and profiles from Finance). See Help on EPPM/Projects and the 1NT scope coverage. SAP Help Portal-Overhead Accounting-Projects

Why is it not under EPPM in CBC? In SAP Central Business Configuration, detailed config activities appear in the Product-Specific Configuration phase and launch in the S/4HANA Cloud system; organisation is by LoB (Finance), not by EPPM. SAP Learning-Introducing SAP Central Business Configuration

If you still do not see 104073 in CBC, double-check your project is in Product-Specific Configuration and that your CBC role lets you launch config activities.

Let me know if you need further information

With best regards

Chuma

entry.title: Solution for sending back broken materials between different legal entities
entry.content:
Hi Guys,

 

I want to ask a question and hope to get any help.

We use SAP ECC on a global single instance with diffent business units worls wide.

Actual we want to implemtn the following use case:

 

We have some plants in diffeent countries which should work together.

Plant B should do some work for plant A. 

Plant A sends material to plant B via sales order FOC. Plant B are consuming this materials from their own storage. Since this material is for warranty use, Plant B get back some broken materials in storage via service order. 

Plant A should do the NCR Process for those materials, because they bought it in their own legal entity. So, in normal, plant B creates a sales order to plant A to send back the materials FOC.

What shoud be the best way to get the broken materials back from plant B to A? We want to prevent a sales order for every single material. Is there any other way to get them back to plant A?

 

Thanks in advance for any help.

 

KInd regards

Christian

entry.title: Re: WHT tax issue in Vendor Invoice Posting
entry.content:
Hi Priya,

@Priya2310 

Below is WHT determination flow

LevelSource Table / ObjectDeterminesStandard Behavior / Notes
Vendor MasterLFBW (Company Code Data for Vendor)Default WHT Type & CodeMultiple WHT codes can exist; all are proposed during invoice creation.
Company Code / Country SettingsT001, T059Z, T059PWHT rules per countryDefines calculation base, thresholds, and WHT type combinations.
G/L AccountSKA1, SKB1, FS00WHT relevance flagDetermines if account is subject to withholding tax.
Material / Material GroupMARA, EKPO-MATKLIndirect WHT impact (custom logic)Standard SAP doesn’t use material group for WHT; needs enhancement if required.
Vendor Country / RegionLFA1-LAND1WHT applicability regionUsed in country-specific WHT procedures (e.g., India, Brazil).
Custom MappingZ_WHT_RULES (custom table)Custom-defined WHT logicYou can define mapping: G/L → WHT Code or Material Group → WHT Code.


Business Problem

AreaDescription
Current ProcessCustom program parks invoice automatically after MIGO.
IssueVendor master has multiple WHT types/codes, all appear in the invoice.
RequirementRetain only one mandatory WHT code per document (automatically).
ChallengeManual correction in MIR6 is time-consuming for large volume.


Possible solution and Approaches

OptionTechnical ComponentPurposeDetails
1BADI_MRM_HEADER_DEFAULT / BADI_MRM_ITEM_CUSTFIELDSAuto-filter WHT codes during invoice creationDetermine correct WHT code and remove others before parking/posting.
2Custom Z-report (ZWHT_ANALYSIS_REPORT)Analyze & correct existing parked documentsDetect multiple WHT codes and replace with valid one using BAPI.
3Z-table (Z_WHT_RULES)Store custom determination logicMaintains mapping between G/L, Material Group, Vendor Group and valid WHT Code.


WHT Determination Logic Example

ConditionSource FieldDetermination LogicWHT Code
Expense G/L 400000–499999BSEG-HKONTIf in range, apply service TDSTDS1
Material PurchasesEKPO-MATKLBased on material groupTDS2
Foreign VendorLFA1-LAND1 ≠ T001-LAND1Foreign WHTTDSF
Contractor Group VendorsLFA1-KTOKK = ZCONContractor TDSTDSC


Z-Report Design (Sample - ZWHT_ANALYSIS_REPORT)

ComponentDescription
Selection ScreenCompany Code, Vendor, Document Date, PO Number, Determination Mode (By G/L / Material Group / Custom Mapping)
Step 1: Read InvoicesFetch from RBKP (Header) & RSEG (Item) where BLART = 'RE'.
Step 2: Read WHT DataFrom WITH_ITEM using invoice number & fiscal year.
Step 3: Determine Valid WHT CodeUse Z-table (Z_WHT_RULES) or rule-based logic.
Step 4: Compare & FlagIdentify invoices with multiple or incorrect WHT codes.
Step 5: Output / CorrectionALV output with simulation & correction mode using BAPI_INCOMINGINVOICE_CHANGE.

Output Columns (ALV Report)

FieldDescription
Invoice No.From RBKP-BELNR
Fiscal YearFrom RBKP-GJAHR
VendorFrom LFA1-LIFNR
G/L AccountFrom BSEG-HKONT
Existing WHT CodesFrom WITH_ITEM-WT_WITHCD
Valid WHT CodeDerived via logic or Z-table
Action Required“Keep / Delete / Correct”
Correction Status“Pending” / “Updated”

Key Tables Involved

Table NameDescription
RBKPInvoice Header Data
RSEGInvoice Item Data
WITH_ITEMWithholding Tax Line Items
LFBWVendor Company Code Data (WHT defaults)
T059P / T059ZWHT Configuration Tables
BSEGAccounting Document Line Items
Z_WHT_RULESCustom Mapping Table (for G/L or Material Group based logic)

Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,

entry.title: Re: Settling an Asset Under Construction (AuC) from an In...
entry.content:
Hi @AlvaroFernandezMorales ,

AuC Settlement from Investment Projects

TopicKey Points / ExplanationSAP Transactions / Notes
ConceptAuC (Asset Under Construction) collects investment costs from projects until completion; settlement moves these to the final fixed asset.—
Your ScenarioInvestment Profile has no Asset Class; Asset Class used has “Settlement by Line Items” active. System won’t auto-create AuC; manual process needed.—
Settlement by Line ItemsEach posting is stored as a separate line item and settled individually to the final asset. Provides detailed cost tracking vs. total settlement.Used when “Investment Measure” not active.
Effect of Missing Asset ClassNo automatic AuC creation; AuC must be manually created (AS01) and linked to project. Manual settlement configuration required.AS01, CJ20N, CJ2D
Recommended Process Flow1️⃣ Create AuC manually (AS01) → 2️⃣ Assign to WBS/Project (CJ20N) → 3️⃣ Post costs → 4️⃣ Define settlement rule (AIAB/CJ2D) → 5️⃣ Execute settlement (AIBU/CJ88).AS01, AIAB, AIBU, CJ88
Settlement Scenarios- Auto (Profile + Asset Class): WBS → AuC → Final Asset (CJ88) - Manual (No Asset Class): WBS → Manual AuC → Final Asset (AIAB/AIBU) - Direct AuC: FI posting → AIBU → Final Asset.Depends on configuration
Best PracticeKeep configuration consistent — use either full Investment Profile automation or manual method. For this case, use manual AuC creation and settlement.Manual: AIAB/AIBU Automatic: CJ88
Final SettlementOnce project completes, settle AuC balance to final fixed asset to clear AuC and capitalize asset value.AIBU / CJ88
Key SAP TransactionsAS01 – Create AuC CJ20N / CJ2D – Assign/define rule AIAB – Prepare settlement AIBU – Execute settlement CJ88 – Project-based settlementUse AIAB/AIBU for manual; CJ88 for automatic
Quick Summary- No Asset Class → manual AuC creation required - “Settlement by Line Items” → individual cost settlement - Manual settlement via AIAB/AIBU - Automatic settlement only if Asset Class maintained in profile.—


If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback. Used GenAI
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Re: Step-by-Step: Implementing Generative AI with SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
That’s a great point — thanks for bringing it up! Yes, GraphRAG and the new HANA Cloud Knowledge Graph engine can definitely enhance LLM responses, especially when working with structured enterprise data. They allow us to retain relationships and semantics more naturally compared to the traditional RAG approach, which relies on converting tabular data into text embeddings.

In this blog, I focused on a practical RAG setup using HANA Cloud Vector Engine, since it’s something many teams can implement quickly with their existing calculation views. Combining GraphRAG with HANA’s Knowledge Graph is a powerful next step.

entry.title: Migration steps from JDK-17 to JDK-21 using OpenRewrite recipes in SAP Commerce Cloud 2211
entry.content:
I have done the following steps in one of my projects recently and it gives desired output as expected.  
Step 1:  Prepare your local SAP Commerce 2211 env with JDK-17:  Download the following jar files and place the platform directory of your SAP Commerce workspace. 

  •       init.gradle
  •       sap-commerce-framework-update-recipes-1.1.1.jar
  •       yant.jar

Step 2 :  Build and Initialize your SAP Commerce using the following commands. (These commands should be executed in the platform directory) 

  •   . ./setantenv.sh
  •   ant clean all
  •   ant initialize      

Noe: Make sure your local setup still pointing to jdk-17

Step 3 :  Generate and adopt the gradle configuration: Since open rewrite runs as a gradle plugin, we have to run the below command in the platform directory to generate the gradle related files. 

  •  ant gradle 
  •   gradle wrapper --gradle-version 7.3.3
  •  ./adapt-build-gradle.sh
  •  ./gradlew assemble     ( verify gradle build works )

Note : If you face any error, then copy yant.jar file into "/hybris/bin/platform/bootstrap/bin" folder and re run the above steps. 

Step 4 : Add the following require extensions in extensioninfo.xml file if you face any build errors. 

{projectName}backoffice  -      <requires-extension name="cloudcommons"/>
{projectName}core             -       <requires-extension name="cmsfacades"/>

Step 5 : Set Environment Variable: Tell gradle where the OpenRewrite recipe JAR is located by running the below command

   export REWRITE_JAR_PATH=/{{your-folder-path}}/core-customize/hybris/bin/platform/sap-commerce-framwork-update-recipes-1.1.1.jar

Step 6 : Unlink the git repo: This can be done by renaming the .git file.  (Ex : .git to .gitTemp)

Step 7 : Run the core automation command to migrate the java files in your custom extensions: 

./gradlew rewriteRun \
--init-script="/{{your-folder-path}}/core-customize/hybris/bin/platform/init.gradle" \
-PcommerceMigrationPattern="^(../custom/{projectName}core).*" \
--no-daemon \
-Dorg.gradle.jvmargs=-Xmx16G \
-Drewrite.activeRecipe=com.sap.cx.rewrite.java.SelectiveCommerceCloudFrameworkUpdate

Repeat this step for all your custom extensions one by one. The entire process will take few hours depends on project files count and size.  

Step 8 : Switch to JDK-21 and Link git repo: Download and install the sap machine jdk-21 using this link: https://sap.github.io/SapMachine/ . Then switch your local setup to JDK-21 and link the git repository by renaming .gitTemp to .git

Step 9 : Rebuild : Rebuild and re-initialize your local setup using the below commands. 

  •   . ./setantenv.sh
  •   ant clean all
  •   ant initialize      

Now your local setup is migrated to jdk-21. If you face any import or runtime related errors that  has to be fixed manually. 

Limitations: This open rewrite recipes can't fix the gradle and jsp files. So manual update required.

entry.title: Performance Difference Observed Between IIB and SAP IS – Database Query Response Time
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I am an IBM Integration Bus (IIB) resource currently working on a migration project where I’m assisting the SAP Integration team by providing the IIB landscape and architecture required for migration to SAP Integration Suite (SAP IS).

As part of a small performance comparison and feasibility test, I simulated a very basic database interaction scenario in SAP IS and observed a significant difference in response time compared to IIB.  I would appreciate guidance on whether this is expected behavior or caused by trial environmental limits.
[Note]:I also tried interacting with IBM MQ SAAS and compared SAP IS and IBM IIB results, again, ending with similar situation(not covered in this Post).

Test setup and observations:

  • I created a SAP HANA Cloud (trial) database for testing.
  • Added a single test table containing only 3 rows of static data.
  • Built a simple SAP iFlow with:
    • An HTTP Sender Adapter to invoke the flow.
    • Three simple SELECT statements(3 calls) to the HANA DB (no transforms, no mappings).
    • No other processing steps.
  • When I invoke the iFlow via HTTP, the total response time is around 7–10 seconds consistently.
  • For comparison, I implemented the same logic in IIB (connected to an SQL Server) and observed typical response times of 100–200 ms. (Occasionally the first call after a long idle takes ~500–700 ms.)

Additional context:

  • The SAP IS trial account is hosted in the US East (VA)-AWS region, whereas the SAP HANA Cloud trial database is in the Singapore Azure region.
  • In the IIB scenario, both IIB runtime and the SQL Server database are co-located in the same data center, likely explaining the ultra-low latency observed there.
  • The http request is initiated(for both tests) using postman from Cloud PC somewhere in US.
  • I understand that cross-region latency can contribute to higher response times, but a difference of 7–10 seconds vs 100–200 miliseconds still feels unusually high for such a lightweight query.

Primary question:

Is the observed delay in SAP IS due to the HANA Cloud trial environment (resource throttling, cold starts, or connection setup time on every request sent), or is there inherent overhead in SAP IS runtime for such DB interactions?

Specific areas where guidance would help:

  • Does SAP IS / DB adapter use connection pooling or persistent connections to the database?
  • Are there known limitations in trial HANA or IS tenants that can cause high round-trip time?
  • Are there runtime or adapter-level settings to minimize latency for repeated database operations?
  • Would response time improve noticeably in a production-grade tenant (same region) setup?

I would greatly appreciate any insights, documentation references, or configuration tips to help understand and potentially improve this response time behavior.

-Dhruv

entry.title: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 1: Environment Setup
entry.content:
This is Part 1 of a 4-part hands-on workshop series on building AI-powered conversational skills using SAP Joule Studio.

  • Part 1: Environment Setup
  • Part 2: Creating Actions with OData V4
  • Part 3: Developing Conversational AI Skills
  • Part 4: Process Automation Integration

Workshop GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Tenx/joule-studio-s4hana-sales-order

Overview

In this module, you'll create your development environment to enable connectivity between your Joule skills and backend systems. This step is essential for ensuring your skills can access the S/4HANA Cloud system.

Prerequisites

  • Access to an SAP BTP tenant configured for Joule and Joule Studio
  • Completion of BTP Joule and Connectivity with S4HANA setup
  • Basic understanding of SAP BTP and destinations

What You'll Learn

  • How to create a development environment for testing Joule skills
  • How to verify destination associations are working correctly
  • How to validate your environment is ready for development

Estimated Time

5 minutes

Create a Development Environment

1. Open the SAP Build Lobby.

Tip: The lobby is a central page for creating, accessing, and managing your projects in SAP Build.

2. Choose Control Tower, then choose Environments.

3. Choose Create. In the popup, enter a name and description, then choose Create.

4. Choose your environment, then choose the Joule tab.

Note: Since this is a new environment and you have not yet deployed a Joule skill, there is no data and you cannot launch the standalone Joule Digital Assistant.

Next Steps

In the next part, you'll learn how to create action projects that use this destination to connect to the S/4HANA Cloud backend system using OData V4 API.

Continue to Part 2: Create Action Projects

Part 1 of 4 | Joule Studio Workshop Series

Full Workshop: GitHub Repository

entry.title: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 2: Creating Actions with OData
entry.content:
This is Part 2 of a 4-part hands-on workshop series on building AI-powered conversational skills using SAP Joule Studio.

  • Part 1: Environment Setup
  • Part 2: Creating Actions with OData V4
  • Part 3: Developing Conversational AI Skills
  • Part 4: Process Automation Integration

Workshop GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Tenx/joule-studio-s4hana-sales-order

Overview

In this module, you'll learn how to create action projects from live OData services. Actions are the building blocks that connect your Joule skills to external systems, enabling data retrieval and business operations.

Prerequisites

  • Access to an SAP BTP tenant with Joule and Joule Studio
  • Completion of Part 1: Associate Environment
  • Basic understanding of OData services

What You'll Learn

  • How to create action projects from OData V4 services
  • How to configure input and output parameters
  • How to test actions before using them in skills
  • How to publish and release actions for use

Estimated Time

20 minutes

Understanding Actions

Actions are used in SAP Build Process Automation to connect processes with external systems, be it SAP or non-SAP systems, and to make GET, POST, PATCH and other calls. Actions created here can be consumed directly in a Joule skill created in Joule Studio.

API Focus: In this tutorial, you will create an action project using the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sales Order (A2X) OData V4 API. This API provides create, read, and update capabilities for sales orders using the latest OData V4 specification. Official reference: CE_SALESORDER_0001

Step 1: Create Action Project for Sales Order Service

1.1 Access SAP Build Lobby

1. Open SAP Build Lobby.

2. Under Connectors, choose Actions, then choose Create.

1.2 Choose API Source

3. In the Choose an API Source popup, under API Specification, choose SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

4. Choose SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.

5. Search for "Sales order (a2x) ODATAV4" and click the Search button.

6. Choose "Sales Order (A2X)" OData V4 service.

1.3 Create Action Project

7. Use the default project name and description, then choose Create.

8. Select the following two GET operations:

  • Get entity from SalesOrder by key - /SalesOrder/{SalesOrder}
  • Get entities from related _Item - /SalesOrder/{SalesOrder}/_Item

Then choose Add.

9. Choose the Test tab and enter 485511 as the test value for SalesOrder.

1.4 Test the Action

10. Make sure the correct destination has been selected, then choose Test to execute the action.

1.5 Release and Publish

11. Choose Release to make the action available for use, then confirm in the popup.

12. Choose Publish to make the action available in the library, then confirm in the popup.

Troubleshooting

If you encounter issues during action creation:

  • Connection Issues: Verify that your destination is properly configured and accessible
  • API Selection: Ensure you're selecting the correct OData V4 service from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Test Failures: Check that the test value (485511) is valid and the destination has proper permissions
  • Release/Publish Issues: Ensure you have the necessary permissions to release and publish actions

Next Steps

In the next part, you'll learn how to create Joule skills that use this action to provide intelligent conversational capabilities.

Continue to Part 3: Create Skills

Part 2 of 4 | Joule Studio Workshop Series

Full Workshop: GitHub Repository

entry.title: Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC)
entry.content:
Picture 1: Intelligent Enterprise Business Steering with SAP

MOTIVATION

In today's fast-paced business world, the ability to effectively steer and lead an organization is fundamental for achieving strategic goals and maintaining a competitive edge. A key success criterion is the capacity to fully harness and derive value from organizational data. Many companies struggle with data problems, such as fragmented information, outdated systems, and the super important task of preparing data for emerging technologies like AI. Recognizing these challenges, we are excited to introduce a blog series dedicated to showcasing the substantial business value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in the context of planning and analytics.

The motivation behind this initiative is to provide a comprehensive exploration of how SAP BDC capabilities as essential instruments, facilitating robust strategic alignment and guiding effective decision-making processes across diverse organizational requirements. We aim to illustrate how SAP BDC, equipped with powerful data management, planning, analytics and innovative AI capabilities, empowers organizations with enhanced business steering agility by providing real-time insights, streamlined data management, and automated decision support – going from insights to action, helps mainly leaders guide their businesses with precision.

Our blog series will provide valuable insights for decision-makers seeking to harness SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to enhance operational efficiency, optimize resource allocation, and achieve long-term objectives. By featuring detailed planning & analytics topics, the series will illustrate the transformative impact of SAP BDC in addressing the operational complexities of today’s business environment. This first introductory blog post will spotlight the strategic advantages of SAP BDC, particularly in the context of Business Steering, setting the stage for a deeper exploration of its benefits throughout the blog series.

There are several blog posts in the series that will cover advantages of SAP BDC in the context of business steering, so please stay tuned for the upcoming blogs:

  1. The Value of SAP BDC in the context of business steering 
  2.  Planning & Analytics is an essential part of SAP BDC  
  3. Key Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC (THIS BLOG POST)
  4. Is AI going to “retire” a dashboard?
  5. Simulations, a game changer in today’s volatile world
  6. Extend existing planning scenarios of SAP BPC/BW-IP in SAP BDC 
  7. Real-time steering with LIVE planning
  8. PaPM - The role of business calculation engine in business steering
  9. Self – service analytics and real time business steering
  10. Business steering powered by AI agents
  11. Leverage data products in the context of planning & forecasting
  12. Introducing AI/ML capabilities by SAP Databricks

INTRODUCTION

In our previous blog post, @BlazZabukovec highlighted how Planning & Analytics plays a vital role in SAP BDC by enhancing decision-making, boosting efficiency, and strengthening strategic alignment to drive organizational performance and business value.

So, what exactly makes up the SAP BDC “magic sauce”? Let’s dive in and unpack it. I will take you behind the scenes to explore the core Planning & Analytics components of SAP BDC - powerful solutions that help businesses streamline planning, improve decision-making, and foster collaboration across departments. By diving into these capabilities, you will see how SAP BDC provides a trusted, unified platform that enables organizations to achieve more effective enterprise planning and analysis.

SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD ANATOMY

To start, we will explore the key features and innovations of SAP BDC to understand its core functionality and how it empowers effective enterprise planning and analysis. SAP BDC is a fully managed Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) solution provided by SAP. Customers simply subscribe to access and consume its powerful data services. Built on the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), SAP BDC leverages foundational services that ensure scalability, security, and seamless integration across the enterprise ecosystem. At its core, SAP BDC harmonizes data from both SAP and non-SAP sources into a unified semantic layer of trusted information. This unified data foundation enables organizations to perform planning, advanced analytics, fuel artificial intelligence, and derive actionable insights. By integrating structured and unstructured data across business processes, SAP BDC empowers companies to bridge transactional and analytical systems, driving intelligent, data-powered growth.

Picture 2: SAP Business Data Cloud Anatomy

SAP BDC builds on the strengths of existing SAP solutions, each contributing a vital layer to the overall architecture:

  • SAP Datasphere: Provides the data integration and modeling layer, ensuring consistent, trusted data across sources.
  • SAP Analytics Cloud: Delivers the planning, forecasting, simulation and analytics into a single solution.
  • SAP BW: – When already in use, SAP BW can serve as a data source, enriching the overall data landscape with historical and structured information. You can materialize the BW data as custom data products in SAP BDC (BW Data Product Generator).

To complement these established tools, SAP BDC introduces new, powerful components and innovations designed to extend planning, analytical and data management capabilities:

  • SAP Databricks: Equips data scientists with advanced AI and machine learning development tools to unlock predictive and prescriptive insights.
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Foundation Services: Provides centralized management of SAP and non-SAP data, ensuring governance, scalability, and efficient data lifecycle handling.
  • End-to-end data lifecycle managed by SAP: A key innovation of SAP BDC is that it automatically integrates and harmonizes data from all SAP LoB solutions, including S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, and Fieldglass. Data from these sources is replicated in real time, eliminating the need for customers to manually prepare and combine SAP data. With SAP managed Data Products in SAP BDC, you eliminate the heavy lifting of extraction, transformation, and pipeline maintenance. This allows organizations to focus on high-value projects, such as delivering Planning, Analytics, AI solutions, rather than time-consuming data preparation.
  • Unified Data Foundation: With SAP BDC, data from all SAP applications is unified under a single domain model. When multiple systems define the same entity - like a customer or product - SAP BDC brings them together under one harmonized definition. SAP BDC offers curated, reusable, and semantically rich data products- trusted assets delivered by SAP as the backbone of planning, advanced analytics and AI applications. Business users no longer need to worry about data origins; they work with consistent, trusted information. Plus, all valuable metadata from the source systems is preserved, ensuring no business context is lost during replication. Everything is grounded in trusted business context - so your AI isn’t guessing, it’s truly understanding.
  • Intelligent Applications: SAP BDC delivers ready-to-consume, fully managed by SAP Intelligent Applications that make planning and advanced analytics a business user task - not IT’s. Intelligent applications aren’t just static input forms or dashboards. They are dynamic, AI-powered systems of engagement that continuously learn from your business data, understand context, and act with precision. By bringing together curated data products, business semantics, and AI agents, these applications can reason, recommend, and even automate - whether you’re working in finance, supply chain, procurement, or HR. Planning and analytic workflows become proactive, decisions happen in real-time, and your business becomes more adaptive with every interaction. 

SAP BUSINESS DATA CLOUD ARCHITECTURE

Let’s take a closer look at the architecture of SAP BDC to understand how its core components work together to deliver value. As highlighted earlier, by unifying and managing data across the enterprise, SAP BDC establishes a trusted foundation that simplifies planning, strengthens analytics, and empowers smarter, faster decision-making. 

Picture 3: SAP Business Data Cloud Components

Here is a closer look at the core components and their roles:

  • Source Systems: The journey begins with source systems, which include both SAP (e.g., SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, SAP SuccessFactors) and non-SAP systems. SAP bundles business data from these systems into entities such as tables and views, combining them to represent specific business scenarios - like Sales, Spend, HR and Finance Performance, Margin Analysis, Substainable Business Performance, Working capital - before replicating them to SAP BDC.
  • Foundation Services: Once replicated, data is harmonized, transformed, and enriched in the Foundation Services, becoming reusable Data Products. Hosted on SAP HANA Cloud and Data Lake files, this layer fully manages integration, transformation, and cleansing, enabling seamless access for any planning and analytics use case.
  • SAP Datasphere: at the heart of SAP BDC, SAP Datasphere defines the data model for data products. It powers both pre-delivered Intelligent Applications and custom models, which can be extended with AI or machine learning. SAP Datasphere also manages analytical roles and data access, ensuring the right users see the right data. Mainly it serves as the foundational data layer for all planning and analytics use cases.
  • SAP Databricks: brings advanced analytics to SAP BDC through AI, machine learning, and pro-code engineering. Data products and planning models can be shared seamlessly (delta sharing protocol) between SAP BDC and SAP Databricks, enabling data scientists to enrich analytics and planning scenarios with sophisticated ML/AI logic. This empowers organizations to identify patterns, forecast outcomes, and automate decision-making. The insights generated in SAP Databricks can be integrated back into SAP Datasphere models, making analytics and planning applications even more powerful and actionable.The example below demonstrates how you can significantly enhance your BDC cashflow data product with advanced ML/AI logic to streamline cashflow forecast and provide deeper financial insights. Stay tuned for a dedicated post where we will explore these use cases in more detail.

Picture 4: Enrich BDC Data Products with ML/AI insights

  • SAP BW / SAP BW/4HANA: With its long history in SAP’s data and analytics ecosystem, SAP BW brings a wealth of legacy objects that remain valuable today. In SAP BDC, both SAP BW NetWeaver Cloud, private edition and SAP BW/4HANA Cloud, private edition can be integrated, allowing BW objects to be onboarded as fully usable data products (as highlighted in the SAP BDC Anatomy section). 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC): is an all-in-one enterprise planning solution that empowers businesses to analyze, plan, budget, forecast, and predict. With SAC, businesses can perform comprehensive planning, budgeting, and forecasting, make data-driven decisions with built-in business intelligence, gain trusted insights and automated forecasts powered by predictive analytics. It allows organizations to simulate multiple scenarios in a sandbox environment and facilitates cross-department collaboration through dynamic workflows. 
  • SAP BDC offers the SAP Seamless Planning approach, which tightly integrates SAP Analytics Cloud with SAP Datasphere. This allows SAC planning model data - including facts and master data - to be stored directly in SAP Datasphere. By blending live actuals and plan data through Datasphere’s capabilities, and referencing data in planning models without replication, organizations can significantly reduce their overall data footprint. This approach ensures real-time data availability while enabling advanced processing and extensibility scenarios through the combined power of SAP Datasphere and SAP Databricks. ( Seamless planning between SAP Analytics Cloud and ... - SAP Community )
  • Intelligent Applications: Intelligent Applications were described already at the SAP BDC Anatomy paragraph. Beyond custom planning input forms and visualizations, SAP BDC provides ready-to-consume SAP-managed Intelligent Applications via SAP Business Technology Platform. Actually they reduce time-to-value for data analysis and planning. For a comprehensive list of available SAP Intelligent Applications, please refer to the link. 
  • SAP Business Data Cloud Cockpit: is a key component in the SAP BDC landscape, providing users with easy access to pre-delivered Intelligent Applications and Data Products. Through the cockpit, users can quickly install applications, browse available data products, and share them with SAP Databricks to enhance analytics with AI and machine learning capabilities. This tight integration helps organizations build a trusted, advanced data foundation, powering smarter planning and analytics across the business.
  • SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM) is a powerful calculation engine built on SAP HANA that delivers real-time profitability and performance analysis. It enables users to create flexible models, process large volumes of data at high speed, and integrate seamlessly with both SAP and non-SAP systems. When deployed on SAP BDC, PaPM gains access to SAP BDC’s integrated ecosystem - including SAP Datasphere and SAC. Within the SAP BDC landscape, PaPM serves as an advanced calculation engine, empowering organizations to maximize performance and profitability through intelligent modeling and simulation. Combining PaPM and SAC allows users to run advanced profitability calculations and execute sophisticated data processing directly from the SAC interface. This integration enriches the planning process with enhanced computation capabilities and deeper insights.  PaPM also offers a range of prebuilt business scenarios - spanning both cross-industry and industry-specific use cases such as Profitability and Cost Management, Tax Modeling, and Transfer Pricing - to accelerate deployment and value realization.

SUMMARY

SAP BDC is a central hub for enterprise planning and analytics, providing a unified, fully managed platform that helps organizations turn data into actionable insights. Core components - SAP Analytics Cloud, SAP Datasphere, SAP Databricks, SAP BW and Intelligent Applications - enable businesses to streamline planning processes, perform sophisticated analyses, and make faster, more strategic decisions. By harmonizing data from SAP and non-SAP sources, SAP BDC creates a trusted foundation that supports advanced planning & analytics, AI, and intelligent applications. With SAP Profitability and Performance Management (PaPM) in SAP BDC, organizations can run complex cost and profitability simulations, enhancing the accuracy and depth of planning. Collectively, these capabilities establish SAP BDC as a strategic asset for any organization aiming to optimize enterprise planning and drive measurable business value.

Do you want to embark on a journey? Please reach out to your SAP representative and register for your SAP BDC Discovery Workshop!

entry.title: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 3: Developing Joule Skills
entry.content:
This is Part 3 of a 4-part hands-on workshop series on building AI-powered conversational skills using SAP Joule Studio.

  • Part 1: Environment Setup
  • Part 2: Creating Actions with OData V4
  • Part 3: Developing Conversational AI Skills
  • Part 4: Process Automation Integration

Workshop GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Tenx/joule-studio-s4hana-sales-order

Overview

In this module, you'll use Joule Studio to create and deploy a Joule skill that consumes services from SAP S/4HANA Cloud. This is where the magic happens - you'll build an intelligent conversational skill that can interact with users and backend systems.

Prerequisites

  • Access to an SAP BTP tenant with Joule and Joule Studio
  • Completion of Part 1: Associate Environment
  • Completion of Part 2: Create Action Projects

What You'll Learn

  • How to create a new Joule skill project
  • How to configure skill inputs, outputs, and responses
  • How to integrate actions with your skill
  • How to deploy and test your skill

Estimated Time

30 minutes

Understanding Joule Studio

Joule Studio is SAP's AI-powered development environment for creating conversational AI skills. It provides an intuitive interface for building intelligent applications that can understand natural language and interact with backend systems.

Integration Focus: In this module, you'll build a skill that integrates with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Sales Order (A2X) OData V4 API to provide intelligent conversational access to sales order data. Official API reference: CE_SALESORDER_0001

Step 1: Create a Joule Skill Project

1. Open the SAP Build Lobby.

2. Choose Create.

3. Select the Joule Skill tile, then choose Next.

4. Enter name Sales Order Assistant and description Supply Sales Order Info., then choose Review.

5. On the following screen choose Create.

6. Enter name showGeneralInfo and description a skill to show the general header info of a given sales order., then choose Create.

Tip: The description is important because Joule will use it to identify the correct skill to select during a conversation.

Step 2: Configure Skill Parameters

7. Choose Trigger to open the side panel.

8. Choose Parameters, then choose Configure beside Skill Inputs.

9. Click Add Input, enter:

  • Name: SalesOrderNo
  • Description: Sales Order Number
  • Mark Required
  • Choose Apply

10. Choose Design Console. You should see errors (this is normal at this stage).

Step 3: Add First Action - Get Sales Order

11. Choose the + between Trigger and End.

12. Choose Call Action.

13. Choose Browse All Actions.

14. Select the action Get entity from SalesOrder by key and then choose Add.

15. Choose Select a Destination, then choose + Create a Destination Variable.

16. Enter S4HANA_CLOUD_SALES_ORDER and a description, then choose Create.

17. Choose Inputs, then choose the SalesOrder field to open the Skill Content pane.

18. Choose SalesOrderNo from the skill inputs.

Step 4: Add Send Message - General Info

19. Choose the + between the first action and End.

20. Choose Send Message.

21. Choose Open Message Editor.

22. Configure the General Info message card:

  • Type: Card
  • Title: Sales Order: [click to choose SalesOrder in the Data Mapping]
  • Text: [click to choose Sold-to Party in the Data Mapping]
  • Description: This order was created by [click to choose Created By in the Data Mapping].
  • Image: sap-icon://sales-order
  • Status State: Information

23. Add an Action Button:

  • Title: Explore More
  • URL: https://my300187.s4hana.ondemand.com/ui#SalesOrder-manageV2&/SalesOrderManage
  • Image: sap-icon://detail-view

24. Add an Edit Section with title General Info and attributes by clicking to choose values in the Data Mapping:

  • Total Amount: [choose TotalNetAmount]
  • Requested Delivery Date: [choose RequestedDeliveryDate]
  • Delivery Status: [choose OverallDeliveryStatus]

25. Choose Save to persist your message changes.

26. Choose Release.

27. Choose Release in the popup.

Step 5: Add Second Skill - Show Detailed Info

30. Make sure the Sales Order Assistant project is on the status of editable, click Create, then Joule Skill.

31. Enter name ShowDetailedInfo and description A skill to show the detailed items info of a given sales order., then choose Create.

32. Choose Parameters, then choose Configure beside Skill Inputs.

33. Click Add Input, enter:

  • Name: SalesOrderNo
  • Description: Sales Order Number
  • Mark Required
  • Choose Apply

34. Choose the + between Trigger and End, then choose Call Action.

35. Choose Browse All Actions.

36. Select the action Get entities from related _Item, then choose Add.

37. Choose Select a Destination, then select the existing destination variable S4HANA_CLOUD_SALES_ORDER.

 

38. Choose Inputs, then choose the SalesOrder field to open the Skill Content pane. In the Skill Content panel, select SalesOrderNo to map it.

Step 6: Configure Detailed Message (List)

39. Choose the + before End, select Send Message, then Open Message Editor.

40. Configure the Detailed Info message:

  • Type: List
  • Title: Sales Order Items
  • Text: Detailed item(s) are shown below:
  • Image: sap-icon://menu

41. Configure List Items by clicking to choose values in the Data Mapping:

  • List content: [choose value]
  • Image: sap-icon://product
  • Title: [choose SalesOrderItem]
  • Text: [choose OriginallyRequestedMaterial]
  • Description: The volume is [choose ItemVolume] [choose ItemVolumeSAPUnit]
  • Status State: Information

  • Detailed View:
    • Title: Material Info:
    • Attribute: Material Group: [choose ProductGroup]
    • Attribute: Original Plant: [choose Plant]
    • Attribute: Net Weight: [choose ItemNetWeight]
    • Attribute: Unit of Weight: [choose ItemWeightSAPUnit]

42. Choose Save.

Step 7: Deploy and Test

43. Choose your environment and then click Deploy.

 

44. Select the S4HANA_CLOUD destination and click Deploy.

45. Choose your environment, then choose Joule.

46. Choose Launch.

47. Enter Please get me the details for sales order 485511 and choose Send.

 

Next Steps

In the final part, you'll learn how to integrate business processes and workflows into your skills, enabling end-to-end automation with email notifications.

Continue to Part 4: Process Integration

Part 3 of 4 | Joule Studio Workshop Series

Full Workshop: GitHub Repository

entry.title: Re: Error of ME807
entry.content: Okay, if the same error coming again then you have to Check Number Range Object EINA Transaction: SNRO or SNUM Object: EINA Go to SNRO → Enter object EINA → Click “Number Ranges” Check if ranges for document types IL and IN are exhausted If exhausted, click “Change Intervals” → Create a new range (e.g., 5000000000 to 5999999999) Assign this range to IL and IN in customizing Disable Info Update in PO Creation Transaction: ME21N While creating PO, uncheck the “Info Update” checkbox at item level This prevents PIR update and avoids triggering the error Check Update Logs in SM13 Transaction: SM13 Enter your client and user ID Status: ALL Look for failed updates related to EINA or EINE tables Confirm if the error is tied to PIR update Test PO Creation Again Create PO again in ME21N with “Info Update” unchecked Save and check in ME2M or ME23N If PO appears, issue is resolved

entry.title: Re: Error of ME807
entry.content:
Okay, if the same error coming again then you have to Check Number Range Object EINA
Transaction: SNRO or SNUM Object: EINA
Go to SNRO → Enter object EINA → Click “Number Ranges”
Check if ranges for document types IL and IN are exhausted
If exhausted, click “Change Intervals” → Create a new range (e.g., 5000000000 to 5999999999)
Assign this range to IL and IN in customizing

Disable Info Update in PO Creation
Transaction: ME21N
While creating PO, uncheck the “Info Update” checkbox at item level
This prevents PIR update and avoids triggering the error
Check Update Logs in SM13
Transaction: SM13
Enter your client and user ID
Status: ALL
Look for failed updates related to EINA or EINE tables
Confirm if the error is tied to PIR update

Test PO Creation Again
Create PO again in ME21N with “Info Update” unchecked
Save and check in ME2M or ME23N
If PO appears, issue is resolved

entry.title: Re: How can I determine HTTP_METHOD in GET_ENTITY method?
entry.content: IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT parameter loads the instance of interface /IWBEP/CL_MGW_REQUEST and it's protected attributes within the dpc_ext class. The protected attribute 'MR_REQUEST' contains the method which is invoked at the gateway. To get this method simply create a local reference to the interface /IWBEP/CL_MGW_REQUEST, typecast IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT and call the method get_request_details of the same interface through which we can extract the http_method.

entry.title: Re: How can I determine HTTP_METHOD in GET_ENTITY method?
entry.content:
The dpc_ext method during runtime loads the instance of interface /iwbep/cl_mgw_request  into the parameter 'IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT' whose protected attribute 'MR_REQUEST' holds the htttp_method being invoked at the gateway. To get this method within your dpc_ext method, simply follow the below steps. 

  1. Create a local reference to the interface /iwbep/cl_mgw_request in your method. 
  2. Typecast IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT to the local reference created above. Now your local reference will hold the current context of the interface /iwbep/cl_mgw_request.
  3. Call the method 'get_request_details' available within the local reference from step 1 to get the request attributes. 

code snippet given below:

   

    DATA: lcl_mgw_request   TYPE REF TO   /iwbep/cl_mgw_request,
          lv_http_method            TYPE string,
          lv_request                      TYPE /iwbep/if_mgw_core_srv_runtime=>ty_s_mgw_request_context.

     lcl_mgw_request ?= io_tech_request_context.

    CALL METHOD lcl_mgw_request->get_request_details
      RECEIVING
        rs_request = lv_request.

    lv_http_method = lv_request-http_method.

entry.title: BADI_EDOC_TR_INVOICE_CHANGE : how to map a header text to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in the XML file
entry.content:
Dear All,

Requirement : in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, put the header text of a Billing Document in the XML document

I'm implementing the BADI_EDOC_TR_INVOICE_CHANGE to fulfill this requirement.

In the documentation of this BAdI Definition, there is the following paragraph :

"

To map a specific header text of source documents to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in XML files, you can proceed as follows:

  1. Create a custom field in the Custom Fields and Logic app. Use the Sales: Billing Document business context.

You map a specific header text of source documents to this custom field.

  1. In your BAdI implementation, you map the custom field to the Invoice/cbc:Note tag in XML files.

"

I know how to create a Custom Field, but how can "You map a specific header text of source documents to this custom field." ?

The Header Text of a Billing Document is not accessible in a BAdI implementation :

  • Option 1 : CDS :  I_BillingDocumentTextTP : the field "Long Text" is not populated
  • Option 2 : EML : fails, with the error message : Statement "READ ENTITIES" is not allowed with this status
  • Option 3 : API : API_BILLING_DOCUMENT_SRV : fails with Calling "GET_HTTP_REQUEST" "violates transactional contract "FUNCTIONAL"

Many thanks for sharing your ideas.

Kind Regards

Hans

entry.title: Re: Need guidance on Bank reconciliation
entry.content:
Hi Nithin,
As requested, please find below the simplified steps for Bank Reconciliation in SAP
1. Set Up Bank Master Data
Create house banks using transaction code FI12.
Define bank accounts (main, incoming, outgoing) and link them to GL accounts.

2. Configure Electronic Bank Statement (EBS)
Set global parameters for EBS.
Create account symbols (e.g., for bank charges, check issued, check received).
Define posting rules for each account symbol.
Assign transaction types to posting rules.
Link external transaction types to posting rules.

3. Upload Bank Statement
Manual: Enter statement details manually.
Electronic: Upload MT940 or other formats via transaction FF_5 or FEBAN.

4. Automatic Matching
SAP matches bank statement items with open items in the system.
Uses predefined rules and transaction types.

5. Post and Clear Transactions
System posts entries and clears matched items.
Unmatched items are flagged for manual review.

6. Manual Reconciliation (if needed)
Use FEBA or FEBAN to manually match and clear items.
Adjust entries or post corrections if necessary.

7. Review and Finalize
Check reconciliation reports.
Ensure all discrepancies are resolved.
Post final entries to reflect accurate balances.

Hope the above steps help you.

entry.title: Re: Switch off clearing specific to ledger group
entry.content:
Dear Gab,
You are right to be cautious with this setting. In SAP ECC, once the "Clearing Specific to Ledger Group" option is activated for a GL account, especially for P&L accounts, reverting it is not straightforward and may not be directly supported through standard configuration.

The limitations of ECC
No direct reversal: Unlike SAP S/4HANA, ECC does not provide a standard method to deactivate the "Clearing Specific to Ledger Group" flag once it's been set for a GL account.

OSS Note Reference: SAP Note 1646466 confirms that ledger-specific clearing is not supported for GL accounts in ECC, especially for open item managed accounts.

We can do workaround and follow this approach.

Create a new GL account without the ledger-specific clearing flag.
Transfer balances from the old account to the new one.
Update your configuration and reporting to reflect the new account.


Suggested Steps
Create a new GL account:
Ensure it mirrors the original account’s settings except for the clearing-specific flag.
Do not enable open item management if not required.

Transfer balances:
Use manual journal entries or a clearing transaction to move balances appropriately.

Update master data:
Replace the old GL account in relevant configurations (e.g., account determination, cost elements).

Document the change:
For audit and reconciliation purposes, maintain clear documentation of the transition.

If you're planning a migration to S/4HANA soon, you might consider handling this during the conversion process where more flexibility is available.

Hope above workaround solution help you

entry.title: Re: how to generate RFQ in SAP MM Module
entry.content:
Hi Amol,
As requested please find detail process of RFQ. The RFQ is a formal invitation sent to vendors asking them to submit quotations for supplying goods or services. It helps organizations compare offers and select the best vendor based on price, delivery terms, and other conditions

RFQ Process Flow in SAP MM

1. Create RFQ (Transaction Code: ME41)
Path: Logistics → Materials Management → Purchasing → RFQ/Quotation → Request for Quotation → Create

Details to enter:
(a) RFQ Type (e.g., AN – standard RFQ)
(b) Language
(c) RFQ Date
(d) Quotation Deadline
(e) Purchasing Organization & Group
(f) Delivery Date
(g) Plant & Storage Location
(h) Vendor Address
(i) Material Number, Quantity, Unit of Measure

You can create RFQs:
Manually from scratch or Automatically with reference to a Purchase Requisition

2. Maintain Quotation (Transaction Code: ME47)
Vendors respond with their quotations.
You enter the received quotations into SAP using ME47.
Include vendor-specific details like price, delivery terms, and payment conditions.

3. Compare Quotations (Transaction Code: ME49)
SAP allows you to compare multiple quotations side-by-side.
Evaluation criteria include:
Price
Delivery time
Terms and conditions
Helps identify the most suitable vendor


4. Select Vendor & Create Purchase Order (Transaction Code: ME21N)
Based on comparison, select the best vendor.
Convert the accepted quotation into a Purchase Order.
The PO is then sent to the vendor for confirmation and fulfillment.

5. Follow-Up Activities
Monitor delivery and invoice processing.
Update vendor performance records for future procurement decisions.

Hope this have given you complete understanding of SAP RFQ in MM

entry.title: BAdI Implementation for Automatic Warehouse Task Selection in the Deconsolidation Work Center in EWM
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hi, everyone.  in this blog i want to explain the BAdi implementation in the automotive spare parts business, particularly in warehouses dealing with mixed pallets. These pallets often contain many small line items- sometimes 400 or more individual parts in the single case(HU).

When we handle these mixed pallets, we typically deconsolidate the smaller materials and scan them individually as we remove them from the larger pallet. The scanning is done using a keyboard scanner connected to the deconsolidation work center.

Here’s the challenge: sometimes the same material appears across multiple line items in an inbound delivery. For example, one material might appear in five or six different line items. When the warehouse operator scans the material, the system attempts to propose the multiple warehouse task for the same material.

If a material has multiple warehouse tasks in the same handling unit (HU), SAP shows a pop-up asking the user to select the correct task. While this works, it slows down productivity because warehouse operators must make repeated manual selections for each small part.

In this example, we are working with Inbound Delivery 180000463, which contains mixed materials. Within the same case, the same material appears across different line items because, in the Inbound Delivery, it was created and packed under separate line items. Please refer to the images below.

For this example, I have set up a POSC scenario. The POSC process flow is as follows: HUs are unloaded from the door to the Goods Receipt zone, then moved from the GR zone to the deconsolidation work center. At the deconsolidation work center, the materials are deconsolidated, and based on the search strategy, the system determines the final putaway bin.

To simplify this demonstration, I have already created the required warehouse tasks, and the mixed-material handling unit is now available at the deconsolidation work center.

T code-/scwm/dcons - Login to the deconsolidation workcenter

Now, here’s the issue. When I scan a material, the same material is often linked to multiple warehouse tasks, since it appears under different inbound delivery line items.

As a result, the system prompts the user to manually select the appropriate warehouse task. In this example, there are only five tasks to choose from, but in some cases, there can be as many as 20 or 30. This means the warehouse operator has to repeatedly select the each task and then proceed, after which the quantity field is populated.

This manual selection process is not efficient and it consumes a lot of time and reduces productivity.

To improve efficiency, instead of showing a pop-up, we can use a standard SAP BAdI enhancement to automatically propose the first warehouse task and populate the quantity field. This way, the system handles the task selection in the background, reducing manual effort and improving productivity.

To implement this enhancement, we first need to identify the correct BAdI that is triggered after the product is scanned. Here, the system lists the warehouse tasks only after the scanning the product, which means there must be a BAdI connected to fetching that list of warehouse tasks.

We can identify the appropriate BAdI in two ways. The first method is by using the debugger to trace the process and determine which BAdI is being called. In the following example, we will use the debugger approach to locate the correct BAdI.

The known way of finding the BAdi is, setting the breakpoint in the method GET_INSTANCE in the class CL_EXITHANDLER

In this method, when we set a breakpoint in the GET_INSTANCE method, the changing parameter EXIT_NAME will display the BAdI name. This approach helps us identify classic BAdIs.

However, to identify a kernel BAdI, we need to set a breakpoint in the statements CALL BADI and GET BADI. This allows us to trace and determine which kernel BAdI is being triggered during the process.

In the example shown below, the breakpoint was triggered when I scanned the product at the deconsolidation work center. This is the exact point where we need to check the EXIT_NAME variable in the debugger (visible on the right-hand side).

We should continue checking each instance until we find the relevant variable that points to the correct BAdI. To do this, we can execute the program using F8, which will move to the next possible BAdI.

In this case, I observed that no relevant BAdIs were found-it executed completely and then displayed the list of warehouse tasks. This indicates that there is no classic BAdI involved in this step. Therefore, we now need to look for a kernel BAdI (new BAdI) instead.

To find the kernel BAdI, here’s what I do: after scanning the source HU and the material, I activate the debugger by entering the command /h in the command field. Once debugging is switched on, I set a breakpoint at the statements CALL BADI or GET BADI.

When the system reaches these points during execution, the debugger will stop, allowing us to identify the relevant kernel BAdI that is triggered after the scan.

Now, as you can see in the screenshot above, we’ve identified the correct BAdI. The code shows the statement where lo_badi is being called, and it references the method GET_WAREHOUSE_TASK. This appears to be the right place where the system fetches the warehouse tasks after scanning, so we can proceed with our analysis using this method.

Next, I’ll press F5 to go inside the code. Once inside, you can see at the top that the BAdI name and the corresponding method name are displayed. This confirms that we’ve found the correct BAdI.

To validate this further, we can set a breakpoint inside the BAdI implementation. By doing so, we can observe which variables and objects are being captured and what data is being processed. Using this information, we can simulate and test our enhancement logic effectively.

Alternatively, we can also locate the relevant BAdI through SPRO. To do this, go to:
SPRO → SCM Extended Warehouse Management → Extended Warehouse Management → Business Add-Ins (BAdIs) for Extended Warehouse Management.

Under this section, navigate to the master data, and within that, you’ll find the workcenter. There, you can see the BAdI named “BAdI: Determination of Warehouse Task for Deconsolidation"

So, this is another way to identify the relevant BAdI related to the deconsolidation process in EWM.

So, we can now confirm that this BAdI and its method are correct by setting a breakpoint. Once the breakpoint is set, you can observe the parameters, which are mostly related to the warehouse task. This helps validate that we’re working with the right enhancement point.

You can also confirm it by placing the breakpoint using the BAdI implementation ID. Then, execute the process again-when the debugger stops at that point, you’ll know you’ve reached the correct area in the code.

In the image below, it is clearly shown that when I executed the deconsolidation and scanned the product, the system triggered debugging and stopped at the breakpoint we set in the BADI implementation. This confirms 100% that this BADI method is relevant to this place.

You can also see the Locals on the right-hand side, which is very important. The table IS_HUDR contains the HU details, while IV_INPUT shows the scanned material.

Looking at the changing parameters:

IT_WHTA_OPEN lists all the open warehouse tasks. Currently, there are eight entries in this internal table.

CV_WHTA is the changing table where, based on the user’s selection, the system populates the selected quantity.

Now that we have the list of open warehouse tasks from IT_WHTA_OPEN, we can write logic to automatically populate CV_WHTA. Once auto-populated, the system can select the next two warehouse tasks automatically, so the user won’t have to select them one by one.

Please find the below sample code for the ref. 

Now that we’ve implemented and activated the BAdI, we can proceed to check its behavior at runtime through debugging. Since the breakpoint has been set under the specific user ID, it will trigger during execution. From there, we can run the process and observe the flow step by step.

In the above picture, you can see that the breakpoint has been hit. The internal table IT_WHTA_OPEN contains 8 warehouse tasks. There is also a function module used to convert the scanned material number into its unconverted form. The output of this conversion is stored in LV_SCAN_MATID, which you can see on the right-hand side.

Using this unconverted material ID, we search within the internal table IT_WHTA_OPEN. During the loop through this internal table, we compare each entry’s material ID with the scanned material ID. If a match is found, we assign the corresponding TANUM ( warehouse task number) to CV_WHTA, and then exit the loop.

As a result, the system automatically proposes the relevant error task on the front-end screen.

Conclusion:

Through this BAdI, the deconsolidation screen can automatically populate the next warehouse tasks sequentially. This explanation mainly focuses on understanding the BAdI-how to identify it, how it works, and how it will be applied in the deconsolidation process rather than the core POSC process.

I would appreciate your suggestions and feedback. Please note that all testing has been performed on the IDES S/4HANA 2023 system .Thank you.

Best Regards,

Kannan Chokkanathan.

entry.title: Re: MRP Transfer Requirement Not Defaulting Source Storag...
entry.content:
Hi Mahendra,
Please find below the solution. Maintain Source Storage Location in MRP Area Configuration
SAP ECC uses MRP Areas when you plan storage locations separately (Storage Location MRP Indicator = 2). In this case, you must explicitly define the source storage location for the MRP Area.

Please find Step-by-Step Configuration as mentioned below.

1. Create or Maintain MRP Area for Sloc B

  • Transaction: OMIZ or SPRO → Production → MRP → Planning → Define MRP Areas
  • Ensure that an MRP Area exists for Sloc B (destination).
  • If not, create one and assign it to the plant and Sloc B.

2. Assign Source Storage Location to MRP Area

  • Transaction: OMIZ or SPRO → Production → MRP → Planning → Define MRP Areas
  • Select the MRP Area for Sloc B.
  • In the "Storage Location for Stock Transfers" field, enter Sloc A as the source.
  • This tells MRP where to pull stock from when planning for Sloc B.

3. Check Material Master (MRP 4 View)

  • Ensure that the MRP Area is assigned to the material. 
  • You can do this in the MRP Area-specific view of the material master (MM02). 
  • The planning type should be set appropriately (e.g., PD for MRP).

4. Run MRP for the MRP Area

  • Transaction: MD03 (for single material) or MD01 (for total planning)
  • Make sure to select the MRP Area when running MRP.

Hope above solution help you.

entry.title: Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud - Part 4: Process Automation
entry.content:
This is Part 4 (Final) of a 4-part hands-on workshop series on building AI-powered conversational skills using SAP Joule Studio.

  • Part 1: Environment Setup
  • Part 2: Creating Actions with OData V4
  • Part 3: Developing Conversational AI Skills
  • Part 4: Process Automation Integration

Workshop GitHub Repository: https://github.com/Tenx/joule-studio-s4hana-sales-order

Overview

In this final module, you'll learn how to create an automated process and consume it in a Joule skill. This demonstrates how to integrate business processes and workflows into your conversational AI skills, enabling end-to-end automation.

Prerequisites

  • Access to an SAP BTP tenant with Joule and Joule Studio
  • Completion of Part 1: Associate Environment
  • Completion of Part 2: Create Action Projects
  • Completion of Part 3: Create Skills
  • Email has been configured for Process Automation

What You'll Learn

  • How to create an automated process in SAP Build Process Automation
  • How to publish the process to the library
  • How to use the process in a Joule skill
  • How to test the integrated solution

Estimated Time

30 minutes

Understanding Process Integration

In order for a process to be visible in Joule Studio, the process must have been published to the library - you need to remember to release, deploy, and then publish. You publish from within the Lobby.

In this tutorial, you will create a simple automated process for sending an email with sales order information. The process will send email notifications with sales order general and detailed information as the subject and body content.

Step 1: Integrate the Process into a Joule Skill

1. Open the SAP Build Lobby, choose Sales Order Assistant Joule Skill project.

2. Click Create, then Joule Skill.

3. Enter name SendEmail and description Only send email with given subject, recipient, and email body if there is draft mail in previous conversations.

4. Click Create.

5. Choose Parameters, then choose Configure beside Skill Inputs.

6. Choose Add Input three times and enter the following parameters:

Name Description Required

RecipientEmail recipient addressselect
SubjectEmail subjectselect
BodyFormat email body as HTML, replace \n with <br>.select

7. Choose the + between Trigger and End.

8. Choose Run Process.

9. Choose Browse All Processes.

10. Select your SendEmail process and choose Add.

11. Choose the Inputs tab and choose the Recipient field to open the Skill Content panel.

12. Select Recipient in the Skill Content panel to map to the input parameter.

13. Similarly map the Subject and Body fields with the corresponding inputs.

14. Configure Send Message, Choose the + before End.

15. Choose Send Message.

16. Choose Open Message Editor.

17. Enter:

  • Illustrated Message as Message Type
  • Email has been sent! as Title
  • Please check the mailbox as Text
  • New Mail as illustration

18. Click Save.

Step 2: Release and Deploy the Joule Skill

1. Choose Release.

2. In the Release Project popup, choose Release.

3. Choose Show project version to change to the Released version.

4. Choose Deploy.

5. Select your environment and then choose Deploy.

Step 3: Test Joule Skill

1. Open the SAP Build Lobby

2. Choose Control Tower, then choose the Environments tile.

3. Choose your environment.

4. Choose the Joule tab.

5. Choose Launch.

6. Choose New Conversation.

7. Enter Can you show general order info about sales order 485511

8. Choose Send.

9. For more detailed information, enter I need more details and choose Send.

10. You can check if the process has been called by going to Monitoring > Process and Workflow Instances.

Troubleshooting

If you encounter issues during process integration:

  • Process Not Visible: Ensure the process has been published to the library after release and deployment
  • Email Configuration: Verify that email has been properly configured for Process Automation
  • Skill Integration: Check that all input parameters are correctly mapped between the skill and process
  • Deployment Issues: Ensure you have the necessary permissions to deploy to your environment
  • Testing Failures: Verify that the test sales order number (485511) exists and is accessible

Congratulations!

You have completed all modules of the Building Joule Skills for Sales Order Queries in S/4HANA Cloud!

You are now equipped to build sophisticated AI-powered conversational solutions that integrate with SAP and non-SAP systems. Throughout this workshop, you've learned:

  • How to set up and configure SAP BTP for Joule Studio development
  • How to create and manage development environments
  • How to build action projects from OData V4 APIs
  • How to develop conversational AI skills with rich UI components
  • How to integrate business process automation with conversational interfaces
  • How to deploy and test end-to-end solutions

Next Steps

Now that you've completed the workshop, consider:

  • Apply to Your Business: Identify use cases in your organization where conversational AI can add value
  • Explore Advanced Features: Dive deeper into Joule Studio's advanced capabilities
  • Build Custom Solutions: Create your own skills connecting to your specific SAP and non-SAP systems
  • Share Your Knowledge: Help others in your organization adopt Joule Studio

Additional Resources

  • SAP Joule Documentation
  • Sales Order (A2X) OData V4 API Reference
  • SAP Build Process Automation Documentation
  • Workshop GitHub Repository

Part 4 of 4 (Final) | Joule Studio Workshop Series

Full Workshop: GitHub Repository

Thank you for participating in this workshop!

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud Report Formatting (Financial Stateme...
entry.content:
Hello @adnanmaqbool 

Thank you for your question. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud, public edition, the Balance Sheet/Income Statement app (F0708) produces a default PDF preview. SAP does not support replacing this with a custom Adobe form like FIGL_BSAIS_EN, and the app does not utilise Output Parameter Determination (OPD) for its PDF output. This is a known product limitation. SAP Support Portal-3380571 - 'Balance Sheet/Income Statement' PDF template - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

What actions are currently available?Use the app’s Export to PDF/Excel feature. Note that some columns might not be visible in the PDF by design, as documented.  SAP Support Portal-2951269 - PDF output from app Balance Sheet/Income Statement (F0708) does not include all columns

If you need a branded or redesigned financial statement, build it in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) or another reporting layer fed by the same S/4 data, and export that to PDF. (F0708 itself can’t switch to a custom template.) SAP Help Portal-Balance Sheet / Income Statement

For your information, references.

  • KBA 3380571 — It is not possible to change the PDF template in app ‘Balance Sheet/Income Statement’ (F0708). The document confirms that the PDF preview uses a fixed format in Public Cloud. SAP Support Portal
  • KBA 2951269 — Explains why some columns don’t appear in the F0708 PDF export. SAP Support Portal
  • Help: Balance Sheet/Income Statement — Functional scope of F0708 (export options, reporting). SAP Help Portal

Let me know if it helps

With regards

Chuma

Afterwards I am doing a depreciation run on 30/09/2025 where 20,00 EUR is posted to my balance sheet account for accumulated depreciations 240000080. This depreciation run is posted in GL.

entry.title: SAP Asset Performance Management - Transport Management : Import Transport Requests to Target Tenant
entry.content:
This blog outlines one of the promising features of SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) : Transport Management process. 

The transport management functionality in SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) provides organizations with seamless navigation to SAP Cloud Management Service where organizations can view and manage transport requests and details. Organizations can manage the SAP APM Transport content using SAP CTMS (Cloud Transport Management Service) to enable the management of software deliverables across different environments, such as development, test, and production. It allows for the transport of application artifacts and content between these environments and also provides an audit trail of changes and ensuring transparency and accountability.

SAP APM - Transport Management Application

In this blog we will transport "Alphanumeric Risk & Criticality Template"  to SAP APM EIOT tenant from a source tenant.

Prerequisites:

  • One must have the role collection to access SAP CTMS. For more information, please check the link below. Role Collection 
  • Destination must have been configured for SAP CTMS in the source tenant`s subaccount. For more information, please check the link below. Configuring Destinations 
  • Transport Routes and Nodes must have been configured in the SAP CTMS. For more information, please check the link below. Transport Nodes 
  • Before transporting the templates from the source tenant, ensure that the associated objects are present in the target tenant(synchronized from S4 HANA)

Disclaimer: This blog does not showcase "Alert Notification Service" used to issue notifications for specific events - Such as when an import is started and when it`s finished.

If you want to gain a deeper understanding of SAP Asset Performance Management functions, you may access the links below.

  • SAP Asset Performance Management - Ingesting Time Series Data - Derivation & Monitor Rule Management 
  • SAP Asset Performance Management - Visual Asset Health Monitoring (Part-1) 
  • SAP Asset Performance Management - Manage Embedded IoT Metadata Sync 
  • What`s New in SAP Asset Performance Management - Release 2502 
  • Achieving Sustainability With SAP Asset Performance Management By Leveraging Industrial Systems. 
  • Configuring Failure Curve Analytics (FCA) In SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) 

Let us navigate to application " Manage Templates for Risk & Criticality Assessments" in source tenant.

Before we transport, let us first view the content of the "2025_AC_HZ_NL_Alphanumeric" template.

Alphanumeric method is used to determine overall risk and criticality values , i.e.,  Minimum or Maximum. 

For Instance I have chosen one Impact Category, i.e., Operation, and two dimensions with a 5-Point rating scale. 

Mini Note: There can be only two dimensions for Alphanumeric Template, and these are common across all impacts. We can not add new dimensions.

Dimension-1 : Consequence of the failure.

Dimension-2: Likelihood of failure.

Threshold Values.

Now let us transport this template to SAP APM EIOT using the option" Transport".

Select the target tenant from the drop down values and provide a valid description for the transport request.

The transport details can be viewed by clicking on "Go to Details" or by navigating to the Application "Job Manager". If we click on "Go to Details", the system redirects us to the Job Manager Application.

Now let us navigate to the application "Transport Management" and Import the transport request ID 209 to SAP APM EIOT tenant.

Action log of the transport request ID 209.

Before we transport the request ID 209, let us quickly check the SAP APM EIOT tenant for the count of of "Risk and Criticality Templates".

now let us import the transport request ID 209  using the option "Import Selected". The status of the Transport Request is "Initial".

Once the system imports the transport request successfully, the status of the Transport Request changes to "Succeeded".

Let us check the SAP APM EIOT tenant.

 

😊This brings me to the end of the walk through process on SAP Asset Performance Management (APM) - Transport Management. I hope this blog proves useful to the Plant Maintenance team. I look forward to seeing the Plant Maintenance Team leverage this promising feature during SAP APM implementation.

--

Yours Sincerely,

Pardhasaradhi Reddy. Chelikam

My LinkedIn Profile: www.linkedin.com/in/pardhreddyc

entry.title: Why the callback procedure is not called in aRFC/pRFC with Wait?
entry.content:
I've got a simple program to run tasks in parallel, which waits the end of all tasks. That's achieved by using CALL FUNCTION '<RFC-enabled function module>' STARTING NEW TASK ... PERFORMING/CALLING ... ON END OF TASK ...

The tasks are called (can be seen by forcing a short dump in the function module) but the callback subroutine is not called.

What is the problem?

Thanks.

Sandra

It happens with ABAP 7.58 but also with other ABAP versions.

The program is this one:

START-OF-SELECTION.
  DATA task_name TYPE c LENGTH 32.
  DATA rfc_error TYPE c LENGTH 255.
  TYPES:
    BEGIN OF ty_result,
      input_number           TYPE i,
      square_of_input_number TYPE i,
    END OF ty_result.
  DATA results TYPE TABLE OF ty_result.
  DO 3 TIMES.
    CALL FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
         STARTING NEW TASK task_name
         PERFORMING on_end_of_task ON END OF TASK
      EXPORTING  input_number          = sy-index
      EXCEPTIONS communication_failure = 1 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 system_failure        = 2 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 OTHERS                = 3.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)
    ENDIF.
  ENDDO.
  WAIT UNTIL 0 = 1.
  LOOP AT results INTO DATA(result).
    WRITE : / result-input_number, result-square_of_input_number.
  ENDLOOP.
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)

FORM on_end_of_task USING p_task TYPE c.
  DATA result TYPE ty_result.
  RECEIVE RESULTS FROM FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
    IMPORTING input_number           = result-input_number
              square_of_input_number = result-square_of_input_number.
  INSERT result INTO TABLE results.
ENDFORM.

The function module Z_RFC_SQUARE is this one, and it's defined as RFC-enabled:

FUNCTION z_rfc_square
  IMPORTING VALUE(input_number)           TYPE i
  EXPORTING VALUE(input_number)           TYPE i
            VALUE(square_of_input_number) TYPE i.
  square_of_input_number = input_number * input_number.
ENDFUNCTION.

entry.title: Re: Why the callback procedure is not called in aRFC/pRFC with Wait?
entry.content:
The issue is due to TASK_NAME being empty.

If a callback procedure is defined with aRFC or pRFC (PERFORMING/CALLING), the task name TASK_NAME:

  • must be initialized with a non-empty name
  • must be unique. If not unique, the exception COMMUNICATION_FAILURE may happen if one task is running with the same task, and this error message is returned: "RFC task <task name> already open."
  • NB: if TASK_NAME is empty, the callback procedure is not called when the task is ended. Note that the ABAP documentation doesn't describe this behavior.

Here is the working code, the only change is to initialize TASK_NAME with a non-empty and unique value (NB: the function module is unchanged):

 

START-OF-SELECTION.
  DATA task_name TYPE c LENGTH 32.
  DATA rfc_error TYPE c LENGTH 255.
  TYPES:
    BEGIN OF ty_result,
      input_number           TYPE i,
      square_of_input_number TYPE i,
    END OF ty_result.
  DATA results TYPE TABLE OF ty_result.
  DO 3 TIMES.
    task_name = |A{ sy-index }|.
    CALL FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
         STARTING NEW TASK task_name
         PERFORMING on_end_of_task ON END OF TASK
      EXPORTING  input_number          = sy-index
      EXCEPTIONS communication_failure = 1 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 system_failure        = 2 MESSAGE rfc_error
                 OTHERS                = 3.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)
    ENDIF.
  ENDDO.
  WAIT UNTIL 0 = 1.
  LOOP AT results INTO DATA(result).
    WRITE : / result-input_number, result-square_of_input_number.
  ENDLOOP.
  ASSERT 1 = 1. " dummy statement for setting a breakpoint (if debug needed)

FORM on_end_of_task USING p_task TYPE c.
  DATA result TYPE ty_result.
  RECEIVE RESULTS FROM FUNCTION 'Z_RFC_SQUARE'
    IMPORTING input_number           = result-input_number
              square_of_input_number = result-square_of_input_number.
  INSERT result INTO TABLE results.
ENDFORM.

Result:

12.10.2025           Square calculation in parallel           1
---------------------------------------------------------------
         1           1 
         2           4 
         3           9
